text:
You need to ensure that Contoso can use version control to meet the data analytics requirements and the general requirements.

What should you do?

options.text: Store all the semantic models and reports in Data Lake Gen2 storage.
Modify the settings of the Research workspaces to use a GitHub repository.
Modify the settings of the Research division workspaces to use an Azure Repos repository.
Store all the semantic models and reports in Microsoft OneDrive.

explanation: Azure Repos (part of Azure DevOps) is the preferred enterprise solution for Fabric Git integration, aligning with Contoso's requirement to minimize implementation effort. GitHub is also supported, but Azure Repos integrates better with Entra ID. Data Lake and OneDrive do not support Git branching.
detailedExplanation:
## Learning Material

### Why Azure Repos?
According to the Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) capabilities in Microsoft Fabric, workspaces can be integrated with Git to provide version control.

**Supported Providers:**
- Azure Repos ✅ (Azure DevOps)
- GitHub ✅

**Key Points to Memorize:**
- Git integration is configured at the **workspace level**
- You need **Admin permissions** in the workspace to set up the connection
- The requirement for **branching** rules out Data Lake and OneDrive

### Summary Table: Fabric ALM Tools
| Feature | Tool | Key Use Case |
|---------|------|-------------|
| Version Control | Git Integration | Branching, tracking changes |
| Deployment | Deployment Pipelines | Moving content between Dev/Test/Prod |
| Offline Dev | Power BI Project (.pbip) | Local metadata for external Git |

### Analogy
Think of Git integration as a **Time Machine** and **Collaboration Hub** for your data project. Instead of saving files as 'Report_v1', 'Report_v2_Final', you have one live version with full history.

### Further Reading
- [Fabric Git integration overview](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/cicd/git-integration/intro-to-git-integration)
- [Configure Git integration](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/cicd/git-integration/git-get-started)

text:
You need to recommend a solution to group the Research division workspaces.

What should you include in the recommendation?

**NOTE:** Each correct selection is worth one point.
explanation: Domains in Microsoft Fabric are designed to logically group workspaces by department (like 'Research'). They are created and managed in the Fabric Admin portal. OneLake data hub is for consuming data, not configuring governance. Entra admin center manages users/groups, not Fabric Domains.
detailedExplanation:
## Learning Material

### Key Concepts
- **Workspaces:** The primary container for items (reports, lakehouses)
- **Domains:** A 'wrapper' for multiple workspaces to organize by department
- **Capacities:** The 'engine' (F-SKUs or P-SKUs) that powers workspaces

### Summary Table: Fabric Administrative Tools
| Goal | Correct Tool |
|------|-------------|
| Create/Assign **Domains** | Fabric Admin Portal |
| Manage **Security Groups** | Microsoft Entra Admin Center |
| View/Filter **Shared Data** | OneLake Data Hub |
| Configure **Workspace Git** | Workspace Settings |

### Analogy
Think of **Workspaces** as individual folders on a computer. A **Domain** is like a Tag or Library (e.g., 'Legal' or 'Finance') that allows you to instantly see all related folders across the entire system.

### Further Reading
- [Domains in Microsoft Fabric](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/governance/domains)
- [Fabric Admin Portal Overview](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/admin/admin-portal)

text:
You need to refresh the Orders table of the Online Sales department. The solution must meet the semantic model requirements.

What should you include in the solution?

options.text: An Azure Data Factory pipeline that executes a Stored procedure activity to retrieve the maximum value of the OrderID column in the destination lakehouse
An Azure Data Factory pipeline that executes a Stored procedure activity to retrieve the minimum value of the OrderID column in the destination lakehouse
An Azure Data Factory pipeline that executes a dataflow to retrieve the minimum value of the OrderID column in the destination lakehouse
An Azure Data Factory pipeline that executes a dataflow to retrieve the maximum value of the OrderID column in the destination lakehouse

explanation: The semantic model requirement states 'minimize rows added during refresh' (incremental/watermarking). You need the MAX OrderID (not minimum) to only fetch new records. The general requirement to 'minimize maintenance effort' favors Dataflows (low-code) over Stored Procedures (T-SQL expertise required).
detailedExplanation:
## Learning Material

### The Watermark Pattern
To minimize rows added, identify the 'high-water mark' (MAX OrderID in destination), then only load records greater than that value.

### Why Dataflow over Stored Procedure?
| Feature | Stored Procedure | Dataflow |
|---------|------------------|----------|
| Logic | Correct (MAX) | Correct (MAX) |
| Skill Level | High (T-SQL) | Low-code |
| Maintenance | Higher | Lower |
| Requirement Fit | Minimize Rows ✅ | Minimize Rows + Minimize Effort ✅✅ |

### Decision Framework
- **Minimize rows added?** → Use MAX(ID) or Latest Date
- **Minimize maintenance?** → Use low-code tools (Dataflows)
- **Highest Performance?** → Use Stored Procedures or Spark

### Analogy
Imagine adding books to a shelf. Option A builds a robot to check the last barcode—fast but needs an engineer to fix. Option D gives a student a simple checklist (low-code)—easier to maintain.

### Further Reading
- [Incremental refresh in Fabric](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/data-engineering/lakehouse-incremental-refresh)
- [Watermark pattern in Data Factory](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/tutorial-incremental-copy-portal)
